As he rode his horse, a sturdy Mongolian stallion named Khöömei, Halsted noticed a group of nomadic herders gathered around a makeshift campfire. They welcomed him with open arms, offering a steaming bowl of airag, a fermented horse milk beverage that had become his favorite since arriving in Mongolia. Among the herders was a young woman named Oyuna, whose piercing green eyes and fiery spirit reminded Halsted of his own daughter back in England. As they shared stories and laughed together, Halsted couldn't help but notice the subtle yet unmistakable signs of military discipline among the herders. They moved with a quiet confidence, their eyes scanning the horizon with a practiced air of vigilance. It was then that he realized these were no ordinary nomads – they were the vanguard of the Mongolian People's Army, the very force he had been invited to help shape. Over the next few weeks, Halsted worked tirelessly alongside the Mongolian officers, imparting his knowledge of tactics and strategy. He was struck by their eagerness to learn, their natural aptitude for warfare honed by generations of living on the unforgiving steppes. As they drilled and trained, Halsted began to see the outlines of a formidable fighting force take shape.
